articles.headline: A.P. Seeks to Rein in Sites Using Its Content
articles.snippet: As advertising dollars shrink and newspapers close, the news media organization threatens legal action unless sites obtain permission to use articles and share revenue.
articles.abstract: As advertising dollars shrink and newspapers close, the news media organization threatens legal action unless sites obtain permission to use articles and share revenue.
articles.lead_paragraph: Taking aim at the way news is spread across the Internet, The Associated Press said on Monday that Web sites that used the work of news organizations must obtain permission and share revenue with them, and that it would take legal action against those that did not.

articles.headline: Russian Auto Bailout Protects Jobs, Not Efficiency
articles.snippet: A bailout, Russian style, for an auto factory is intended more to ensure peace than to restructure a business.
articles.abstract: A bailout, Russian style, for an auto factory is intended more to ensure peace than to restructure a business.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOLYATTI, Russia  If there is a country that truly needs a car czar, it is Russia, home of the czars  and Lada.

articles.headline: Economy Falling Years Behind Full Speed
articles.snippet: The slack economy’s loss of output is running at $1 trillion a year, and it will take years for employers, investors and consumers to bring it back to full speed.
articles.abstract: The slack economy’s loss of output is running at $1 trillion a year, and it will take years for employers, investors and consumers to bring it back to full speed.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the recession grinds on, more and more of the nation’s means of production  its workers, its factories, its retail outlets, its freight lines, its bank lending, even its new inventions  are being mothballed.

articles.headline: Outlook on Economy Is Brightening, Poll Finds
articles.snippet: President Obama is enjoying some success in rebuilding confidence, according to a New York Times/CBS News poll.
articles.abstract: President Obama is enjoying some success in rebuilding confidence, according to a New York Times/CBS News poll.
articles.lead_paragraph: Americans have grown more optimistic about the economy and the direction of the country in the 11 weeks since President Obama was inaugurated, suggesting that he is enjoying some success in his critical task of rebuilding the nation’s confidence, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney and Megan Thee-Brenan

articles.headline: Muted Signs of Life in the Credit Markets
articles.snippet: Investors are starting to get some nerve back, analysts say, mainly because of federal efforts to get credit flowing.
articles.abstract: Investors are starting to get some nerve back, analysts say, mainly because of federal efforts to get credit flowing.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is hard to miss the news: the stock market has been on a bit of a roll lately. But with far less fanfare, the credit markets, where the financial crisis began, are also showing signs of a spring awakening.

articles.headline: Removing Medtronic Heart Cables Is Hard Choice
articles.snippet: In the next few years, thousands of patients may face risky surgical procedures to remove and replace the Sprint Fidelis, a heart defibrillator cable that has been pulled from the market.
articles.abstract: In the next few years, thousands of patients may face risky surgical procedures to remove and replace the Sprint Fidelis, a heart defibrillator cable that has been pulled from the market.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOSTON  Pulling a medical device off the market is one thing. Removing it from the bodies of thousands of patients is a lot more complicated and dangerous.

articles.headline: Military Budget Reflects a Shift in U.S. Strategy
articles.snippet: Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates announced a budget that cuts traditional weapons programs while adding resources to fight insurgencies.
articles.abstract: Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates announced a budget that cuts traditional weapons programs while adding resources to fight insurgencies.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates announced a major reshaping of the Pentagon budget on Monday, with deep cuts in many traditional weapons systems but new billions of dollars for others, along with more troops and new technology to fight the insurgencies in Iraq and Afghanistan.
articles.byline: By Christopher Drew and Elisabeth Bumiller

articles.headline: ‘No-Risk’ Insurance at F.D.I.C.
articles.snippet: Somehow, in the name of solving the financial crisis, the F.D.I.C. has seemingly been given a blank check, with virtually no oversight by Congress.
articles.abstract: Somehow, in the name of solving the financial crisis, the F.D.I.C. has seemingly been given a blank check, with virtually no oversight by Congress.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation was set up 76 years ago with the important but simple job of insuring bank deposits.

articles.headline: Protests in Moldova Explode, With Help of Twitter
articles.snippet: A sea of young people used text messages and the Internet to appear out of nowhere to protest Communist leaders.
articles.abstract: A sea of young people used text messages and the Internet to appear out of nowhere to protest Communist leaders.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW  A crowd of more than 10,000 young Moldovans materialized seemingly out of nowhere on Tuesday to protest against Moldova’s Communist leadership, ransacking government buildings and clashing with the police.
